pages.text: A piece of natural oak wood can take on virtually any hue; from light beige through brown and red. White oak tends to look more beige-to-brown and red oak looks rosier.
The most prized part of the tree where birch is concerned is the sapwood or outermost section of the tree. Its usually more of a creamy white, but can be almost a pure white in some cases.
Sap and heartwood are in distinguishable in colour. The wood colour is yellowish-white and darkens under the influence of light.
The wood is a light yellow to light brown in color, and has a fine to medium texture. It is typically straight grained, with a coarse, uneven texture.
Acacia wood ranges in color from yellow to golden brown. Aged acacia wood has a reddish or deep brown hue.

Moreover, the same oak tree can have different colors throughout, and both red and white oak stain well, meaning a piece can look as dark as walnut or even brighten a whole room when stained a vibrant hue.
Natural browns and black and gray tones are accented with mellow shades of burgundy and raspberry that make a truly unique and sophisticated color combination.
Some warped wood is quite brown, whereas that sold below has blue, violet, light blue, steel blue, green and rarely even a royal blue color.
